importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Hamas-led attack on southern Israel, which triggered major political and security repercussions and led to ongoing debates over accountability and policy direction in Israel's national security leadership.

The date of the announcement of Hanegbi's firing and the appointment of Gil Reich as acting national security chief, marking a pivotal moment in Israel's leadership transition amid ongoing Gaza tensions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2023 to 2025 reflects the span of Hanegbi’s tenure as national security adviser and the political tensions that culminated in his dismissal, highlighting a critical phase in Israel’s security and governance response to Gaza conflict and the October 7 attacks.

keyTakeAways: Tzachi Hanegbi, Israel’s former national security adviser, has been fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu amid growing tensions over Israel’s war strategy in Gaza.
Hanegbi criticized the government's failure to establish an official investigation into the October 7 Hamas attack, calling for a 'thorough investigation' and admitting shared responsibility.
Gil Reich, the deputy head of the National Security Council, has been appointed as acting head of the NSC following Hanegbi’s removal.
The dismissal has been widely seen as a reflection of deep divisions within Netanyahu’s government, particularly over military strategy and accountability for the October 7 attack.
Opposition figures like Gadi Eisenkot have condemned the move as an attempt to evade responsibility and replace critical voices with compliant officials.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has fired national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi, citing internal divisions over military strategy in Gaza, particularly Hanegbi’s opposition to a full military takeover of Gaza City and his support for a partial deal with Hamas. Hanegbi, who served as national security adviser since 2023, has called for a thorough investigation into the Hamas-led October 7, 2023, attack, admitting shared responsibility. The move has drawn criticism from opposition figures like Gadi Eisenkot, who accuse Netanyahu’s government of evading accountability. In response, Gil Reich, the deputy head of the National Security Council, has been appointed as acting head of the NSC, signaling a shift in national security leadership amid ongoing tensions over Gaza and security policy.
title: Israel’s Netanyahu fires national security chief amid Gaza tensions
